entry.title: BAdI Sorter in SAP BTP ABAP for custom BAdI Definition
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

Recently we've been developing solutions in SAP BTP ABAP environment, and we would like to create some custom Business Add-in (BAdI) and hook its BAdI definition inside our code for customer extension.

It looks good so far, until we came with a question, how to define the sequence for these BAdIs implementation?

In On-Premise world, we used the good old BADI_SORTER but seems like it isn't permitted to use in BTP ABAP environment. Even if it's allowed, I think it is still using the classic elements like dynpro screen, function modules, ... which isn't following the modern strategy from SAP when developing in cloud environment like BTP ABAP.

I've been exploring a bit on the Internet as well as SAP published documentations for SAP BTP ABAP. Unfortunately, I couldn't find any other options to enable sorting of custom BAdI implementations.

Does anyone have any ideas, how to control the sequence of BAdIs in BTP ABAP?

Thank you very much.

Best Regards,

Tan

entry.title: Missing data in SAC Data Analyzer table vs. S/4HANA Report Monitor query result
entry.content:
Hi All ,

I am experiencing a discrepancy between the cost center list displayed in the Data Analyzer table in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) Vs what is shown in the Report Monitor in S/4HANA.

Issue Description

  • The Data Analyzer table is connected to a live model created from a standard CDS view in S/4HANA.
  • When the account hierarchy is set to Level 1, the table correctly shows the total number of cost centers. Table has cost center , account & one more dimension in row , 12 months in the column. 
  • However, when I drill down to the lowest hierarchy level for the account, the resulting cost center list is incomplete. For example, SAC table displays only 20 cost centers instead of 50 concenters data. 
  • In contrast, the underlying CDS view in the Report Monitor (S/4HANA) displays the full set of cost centers.

Observations

  • The only notable difference is the presentation: the Report Monitor displays results in flat structure from the hierarchy view in SAC.
  • I have reviewed several SAP notes regarding table limitations. 3563348 - Data Analyzer : No 'Edit Drill Limitation' option in Data analyzer indicate that Data Analyzer does not have a drill limitation. Despite this, I notice that applying less filters, decreases the cost centers list in the SAC table.
  • I understand that minimizing filters is generally advisable for performance, but finance analysts typically prefer exporting a complete dataset to Excel for detailed offline analysis. Loading the full list in a browser for analysis is less practical.

Please help with the following questions. 

  • Why is the cost center list in SAC Data Analyzer incomplete when the drill level is set to the lowest account hierarchy level, despite no indicated drill limitation?
  • Are there specific workarounds or best practices to enable analysts to export the full dataset (similar to what is available in S/4HANA Report Monitor)?
  • Is there additional documentation or SAP notes that address this specific scenario or known limitation?

Thank you in advance for your support and guidance.

Regards,

Krishna.

entry.title: SAP Datasphere News in September
entry.content:
SAP Datasphere News in September

Another month with two nice new release deliveries ‚ú®

Learn more in my short top features video in September 2025 on YouTube üì∫

In addition, explore the latest updates in our community news blogs and more.

‚ÄÉ

My top features in September

 

Input Parameters in Task Chains and Transformation Flows

You can now define input parameters on the task level of task chains and also for transformation flows. A scheduled transformation flow uses the default value of the input parameter. Input parameters defined in transformation flows can be used in operators within the transformation flow, except for the Python operation in Apache Spark runtime.

A transformation flow executed as part of a task chain receives input parameters from the task chain. This will allow for more flexible usage of task chains and even nested task chains.

‚û°Ô∏è  Creating a Transformation Flow

‚û°Ô∏è  Creating Input Parameters in Task Chains

 

Email notification in Replication Flows

You can setup email notifications to stay informed when individual replication objects fail in a running replication flow. From both the Replication Flow editor or the Flows monitor, you can setup an email notification for failures of an individual object in a replication flow.

‚û°Ô∏è  Configure Email Notification for Replication Flow Failure at Object Level

‚û°Ô∏è  Working With Existing Replication Flow Runs

 

Fiscal Time Dimension

When creating a time dimension view, you now have the option for dimension type Standard and Fiscal Time. You use the new Fiscal Time dimension type to model your fiscal time periods and the columns that define their starts and ends. When you add a fiscal time dimension to an analytic model, a Fiscal Variant variable is created for this dimension. The variable can then be handled like any other variable. Its data type is derived from the fiscal variance column from the fiscal time dimension.

‚û°Ô∏è  More information

 

Structure Support for Analytic Models

In order to create restrictions and calculations across all measures of an analytic model, you can create structures. Structures help you to save time and ensure consistency in your calculations, as you don‚Äôt need to create a formula/calculation for each measure. In the data preview, the structure members are displayed in their own section. When you use a structure member in the drill-down of a preview, the restriction and calculations defined in the structure member will be applied to each measure. Structures can also be used and enhanced in SAP Analytics Cloud. When the analytic model has measures and at least one structure you need to define how the calculations should be prioritized.

‚û°Ô∏è  More information

entry.title: Re: Need to extend F3893 Sales Order Manage V2 fiori App...
entry.content:
To extend the F3893 Sales Order Manage V2 Fiori app to stop the order from saving (simulate order data), you can follow these steps:

1. Use the BAdI for Sales Order Validation:

  • SAP provides a Business Add-In (BAdI) called BADI_SD_SALES_ORDER or BADI_SALES_ORDER for order validation.

  • You can implement this BAdI to simulate order data and prevent the sales order from being saved.

2. Custom Logic for Order Simulation:

  • Implement custom logic in the BAdI to validate the order data (e.g., check if certain conditions are met before saving).

  • To simulate the data and prevent saving, you can use RAISE EXCEPTION or manipulate the status of the order to prevent it from being committed.

3. Enhance the Fiori App:

  • If necessary, extend the Fiori app using the SAP Fiori App Extensibility framework.

  • You may need to create a custom controller or use the SAPUI5 extension for Fiori to add a custom action, like a "Simulate" button, that stops the order from saving.

4. Frontend Logic (Optional):

  • In the Fiori frontend, you can also apply some validation logic through JavaScript or UI5 controllers to prevent the user from clicking the save button under specific conditions.

5. Testing and Debugging:

  • After implementing the logic, test the app thoroughly to ensure that the order behaves as expected (simulated data without saving).

6. Deployment:

  • Once satisfied with the changes, deploy the extended app to your production environment.

entry.title: Re: Is there a way to export all the information within B...
entry.content:
Hello @Luvv_LK 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at Bills of Material & Manage Order Bill of Material for more details.

To summarise, in public cloud, the Explode BOM app only provides hierarchical view and cannot export full BOM data. To enable you export complete BOM details you should:

  • Use the Manage Bills of Material app for manual single-level export, or
  • You use the API_BILL_OF_MATERIAL_SRV to retrieve full multi-level BOMs.

If you need a combined view, then you should create a Custom CDS View joining both of them.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Missing data in SAC Data Analyzer table Vs S/4HANA Report monitor
entry.content:
Hi Team,

I am experiencing a discrepancy between the cost center data displayed in the Data Analyzer table in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) and what is shown in the Report Monitor in S/4HANA.

Issue Description

  • The Data Analyzer table is connected to a live model created from a standard CDS view in S/4HANA. Table has costcenter , account and another dimension in row and 12 months in column. 
  • When the account hierarchy is set to Level 1, SAC table correctly shows the total number of cost centers.
  • However, when I drill down to the lowest account hierarchy level, the resulting cost center list is incomplete.
  • In contrast, the underlying standard CDS view in the Report Monitor (S/4HANA) displays the full set of cost centers

Observations

  • The only notable difference is the presentation: the Report Monitor displays results in flat presentation from the hierarchy view in SAC.
  • I have reviewed several SAP notes regarding table limitations.  As per note, 3563348 - Data Analyzer : No "Edit Drill Limitation" option in Data analyzer, Data Analyzer does not have any drill limitation.
  • Despite this, I notice that applying less filters to the table reduces the list of cost centers in the SAC table. For example, if there are total of 50 costcenters, only 10 costcenters are getting retrieved & displayed if account hierarchy drill level is set to lowest and/or reduce the number of filters.
  • I understand that minimizing filters is generally advisable for performance, but finance analysts typically prefer exporting a complete dataset to Excel for detailed offline analysis. Loading the full list in a browser can introduce delays while scrolling and is less practical.

Could you help clarify the following:

  • Why is the cost center list in SAC Data Analyzer incomplete when the drill level is set to the lowest hierarchy level, despite no indicated drill limitation?
  • Are there specific workarounds or best practices to enable analysts to export the full dataset (similar to what is available in S/4HANA Report Monitor)?
  • Is there additional documentation or SAP notes that address this specific scenario or known limitation?

Thank you in advance for your support and guidance.

Best regards,

Krishna

entry.title: Re: How to prevent automatic apportionment by profit cent...
entry.content:
Hello @SATOSHI_S 

This is a standard document splitting by Profit Center in S/4HANA Cloud. When a voucher has items with multiple Profit Centers (PRCTR) and lines that cannot carry PRCTR like customer/  or vendor recon, some tax/bank lines, the system proportionally distributes those lines across the item PRCTRs to balance the document per profit center. This behaviour can't be switched in Public Cloud.

How can you get  no apportionment outcome?

Via Best practice: Submit one accounting document for each Profit Center. When using the Journal Entry , Post (SOAP) JournalEntryBulkCreateRequest, send a separate JournalEntryCreateRequest for each PC.

For a G/L-only journal, you can retain a single voucher if you explicitly specify the ProfitCenter on each line, including offset and tax lines, calculate tax per PC, and post separate tax lines per PC.

If the document includes customer/vendor reconciliation lines, you cannot assign PRCTR to those lines via the API, as splitting will occur. Therefore, split the posting per PC.

Useful references (Public Cloud)

  • SAP Help-Document Splitting (S/4HANA Cloud) , explains proportional inheritance/splitting by characteristics like Profit Center and why non-assigned lines are distributed.
  • API: Journal Entry ‚Äì Post (Synchronous)  request structure shows the ProfitCenter field on items and the rule that reconciliation lines do not carry PRCTR; post separate documents to control PC

Let me know if you need more information

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.content:

entry.title: Re: Error During Scheduled Job Execution in BD6 Basic Cre...
entry.content:
Hello @nurulaffzan 

Thank you for your question.

When you run Credit Management Jobs in scope item BD6, you may possibly encounter the error about currency/unit conversion. The reason it happens is because the system tries to convert MYR to USD but cannot find a valid exchange rate for the posting date. Even if your company code and credit control area are in MYR, the system still checks the group currency which is USD at the controlling area level. However, you can consider the following to solve that issue:

  • First, check your Credit Control Area currency to confirm what is defined.
  • Second, Use the Maintain Exchange Rates app to maintain a valid MYR to USD exchange rate.
  • Thereafter, ensure to re-run the job.

Have a look at Maintain Exchange Rates & Import Foreign Exchange Rates for more details.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: SAP TechEd Berlin 2025: Where‚Äôs Waldo ‚Ä¶ ah ‚Ä¶ Terraform?
entry.content:
A couple of words about me: 

My name is Christian Lechner and I‚Äôm Product Manager for the BTP CLI as well as for the Terraform activities around SAP BTP.

I love developer experience and want to make their life as well as the life of SAP BTP administrators easier so that they can focus on what really matters when developing business applications and extension.

My Sessions:   

The title of this post already gives a hint. There is no standalone session that deals with Terraform. No need to be sad though, we managed to bring some Terraform magic into the following sessions showcasing that Terraform can help you at various scenarios that might not be obvious at a first glance:

  • XP202 | How to efficiently operate your applications on SAP BTP, Wednesday, Nov 511:15 AM - 12:00 PM CET (deep dive)
  • XP263 | Advanced tools for administrators in SAP BTP, Tuesday, Nov 4, 10:00 AM - 12:00 PM CET (hands-on workshop)
What you will learn about: 

Let‚Äôs start with the deep-dive ‚ÄúXP202 | How to efficiently operate your applications on SAP BTP‚Äù: this session gives more background information on the day 2 tasks when operating cloud native apps.
In this session you will get some insights on what to consider around Terraform focusing on the challenges after you have successfully deployed the infrastructure for your app. Of course, we will also discuss topics like observability and alike as central parts of day 2 operations.
While the session complements the hands-on workshop ‚ÄúXP265 | Master managing cloud-native applications on SAP BTP, Cloud Foundry runtime‚Äù, the hands-on session is no prerequiste for the deep dive.

The second chance to learn about Terraform is the hands-on workshop ‚ÄúXP263 | Advanced tools for administrators in SAP BTP‚Äù. This hands-on workshop puts the spotlight on the FinOps part of SAP BTP and the increasing options SAP BTP offers to deal with this important topic.
A perfect fit for Terraform, right ü§î? Not at a first glance. But here‚Äôs the point: provisioning and managing your account structure with Terraform can make your life much easier when it comes to FinOps as you will ensure a consistent account structure including features like labels that support you in mastering the FinOps challenges. That‚Äôs why you will learn how to set up your accounts via Terraform and how to enhance the account structure in a consistent way keeping you on the light side of the (FinOps) force.

Co-speakers: 

 I have the honor to share the stage with:

  • Keren Rotenberg (@keren_rotenberg) 
  • Michal Keidar (@michal_keidar) 
  • Stephan Klevenz (@sklevenz) 
  • Yaron Livneh (@Yaron-Livneh) 

Other related sessions I recommend:  

As mentioned before the following hands-on workshops might be of interest when working with cloud-native apps in the Cloud Floundry or Kyma runtime:

  • XP264 | Explore how to run cloud-native applications on SAP BTP, Kyma runtime
  • XP265 | Master-managing cloud-native applications on SAP BTP, Cloud Foundry runtime
Related community managed tags you should subscribe to remain informed about this topic: 

DevOps 

Related community topic pages:   

DevOps 

Looking forward to seeing you: 

No matter if you want to start with Terraform or want to get some deeper insights on what‚Äôs up after provisioning your resources with Terraform we got you covered.

Besides the pure learning aspect keep in mind: TechEd was never about learning only but connecting and discussing with peers, so take the chance to learn with and from others on their journey with SAP BTP operations.

Now let‚Äôs hear from you: 

What are your experiences with operational tasks on SAP BTP using Terraform or the BTP CLI? Stumbled across some rough edges that you would like to discuss. Ideas how to improve the experience with Terraform or the BTP CLI?

I‚Äôd love to hear and learn from you ‚Äì let‚Äôs meet at SAP TechEd 2025 and improve the SAP BTP experience together!

entry.title: Self Refining Prompts for a better Customer Experience
entry.content:
Teaching AI applications to Self-Critique

My Experiments with Self-Refining prompts

Most of us treat a prompt like a one-shot instruction. You ask, the model answers, and‚Ä¶ that‚Äôs it. But in practice, good work is iterative: we write a draft, critique it, and then refine. Self-Refine applies that same loop to AI ‚Äî the model acts as writer, critic, and editor in quick succession until the result feels right.

In this post, I‚Äôll share what clicked for me, a simple three-step pattern, and a few mini-experiments you can try (and screenshot) to see the lift for yourself.

The 3-Step Loop (that changed how I prompt)

1) Generate ‚Äì Ask for the initial output.
2) Feedback ‚Äì Ask the model to critique its own output with specific, actionable notes.
3) Refine ‚Äì Tell it to rewrite using only that feedback.
Repeat until it says, ‚Äúno further refinement.‚Äù

This is simple. The magic is in good feedback prompts (‚Äúpoint out tone, missing details, structure‚Äù vs. vague ‚Äúimprove it‚Äù).

How it works (in 10 seconds)

  • Generate: Draft the answer
  • Critique: The model reviews itself (JSON feedback + score)
  • Refine: It rewrites using that feedback
  • Stop: when the score plateaus or hits your bar

Task-specific effectiveness: Self-refinement works better for some task types (code generation, technical documentation) than others (creative writing). Measures vary for each task category.‚Äã

Mini-Experiments

Building a self-improving web search Agent 

Building a Web Search Agent with Self-Improving Prompts
The foundation combines SAP AI Core's Generative AI Hub with LangChain's Google Search wrapper:
```python
# SAP AI Core client setup
ai_core_client = AICoreV2Client(
    base_url=BASE_URL, auth_url=AUTH_URL,
    client_id=CLIENT_ID, client_secret=CLIENT_SECRET,
)
llm = init_llm(MODEL_NAME, temperature=0.0, max_tokens=512)

# Google Search integration
search = GoogleSearchAPIWrapper(k=5)
google_tool = Tool.from_function(
    name="google_search",
    description="Search Google and return the first results",
    func=search.run
)
agent = initialize_agent(tools=[google_tool], llm=llm, agent=AgentType.OPENAI_FUNCTIONS)

#This gives us both a base LLM and an agent that can search the web when needed.
The Three-Prompt Pattern
The self-refinement uses three distinct prompts with clear roles:
Generator Prompt: Creates initial draft without second-guessing
GEN_PROMPT = """You are a careful, precise assistant.
TASK: {task}
Produce the best possible answer. Do not include any self-critique here."""
```
Critic Prompt: Evaluates with structured feedback
CRITIC_PROMPT = """You are a meticulous reviewer. Given the TASK and the DRAFT answer,
1) list EXACTLY 3 concrete issues or improvement opportunities,
2) give a numbered improvement plan,
3) rate current quality from 0‚Äì100,
4) decide if refinement is still needed.

Respond with a SINGLE JSON object and NOTHING ELSE:
{{"issues": ["...", "...", "..."], "plan": ["step 1", "step 2", "step 3"], "score": 0, "stop": false}}"""
```
Refiner Prompt: Applies improvements systematically
REFINE_PROMPT = """You are a senior editor. Apply the plan below to improve the DRAFT.
Keep all correct content; fix issues; increase clarity, correctness, and usefulness.
Return ONLY the improved answer (no commentary)."""```
The key is separating generation from critique to avoid the model sabotaging its own initial work.
The Self-Refine Loop
def self_refine(
    task: str,
    max_iters: int = 3,
    min_delta: int = 2,
    use_agent_for_initial: bool = False
) -> Dict[str, Any]:
    """
    Self-refine loop: GENERATE -> CRITIQUE -> REFINE until stop or plateau.
    Returns final answer and iteration history.
    """
    history: List[Dict[str, Any]] = []

    # 1) Initial draft
    draft = call_llm_text(GEN_PROMPT.format(task=task), use_agent=use_agent_for_initial)
    history.append({"iteration": 0, "draft": draft, "score": None, "feedback": None})

    best = draft
    best_score = -math.inf

    for i in range(1, max_iters + 1):
        # 2) Critique
        critic_raw = call_llm_text(CRITIC_PROMPT.format(task=task, draft=draft))
        critic = extract_json_block(critic_raw)

        # Safety coerce
        issues = critic.get("issues", [])[:3]
        plan = critic.get("plan", [])
        score = int(critic.get("score", 50))
        stop_flag = bool(critic.get("stop", False))

        history.append({
            "iteration": i,
            "draft": draft,
            "score": score,
            "feedback": {"issues": issues, "plan": plan, "raw": critic_raw}
        })

        # Plateau / stop condition
        if stop_flag and i > 1:
            break
        if best_score != -math.inf and (score - best_score) < min_delta and i > 1:
            # No meaningful improvement
            break

        # Track best
        if score > best_score:
            best = draft
            best_score = score

        # 3) Refine
        plan_str = "\n".join(f"- {p}" for p in plan) if plan else "- Improve clarity and correctness."
        refined = call_llm_text(REFINE_PROMPT.format(task=task, draft=draft, plan=plan_str))
        draft = refined

    # Final scoring pass to attach a last score
    final_critic_raw = call_llm_text(CRITIC_PROMPT.format(task=task, draft=draft))
    final_critic = extract_json_block(final_critic_raw) or {"score": best_score if best_score != -math.inf else None}
    final_score = int(final_critic.get("score", best_score if best_score != -math.inf else 0))

    return {
        "task": task,
        "final": draft,
        "final_score": final_score,
        "history": history,
        "final_critic_raw": final_critic_raw
    }
Usage Example
# runner + example usage
def run_task_self_refine(
    task: str,
    max_iters: int = 3,
    min_delta: int = 2,
    use_agent_for_initial: bool = False,
    verbose: bool = True
) -> Dict[str, Any]:
    result = self_refine(
        task=task,
        max_iters=max_iters,
        min_delta=min_delta,
        use_agent_for_initial=use_agent_for_initial
    )
    if verbose:
        for rec in result["history"]:
            it = rec["iteration"]
            pretty_print_blocks(f"Iteration {it} ‚Äî Draft", rec["draft"])
            if rec["feedback"]:
                fb = rec["feedback"]
                pretty_print_blocks(f"Iteration {it} ‚Äî Feedback (score={rec['score']})", json.dumps({
                    "issues": fb["issues"],
                    "plan": fb["plan"]
                }, indent=2))
        pretty_print_blocks(f"FINAL (score={result['final_score']})", result["final"])
    return result

# Example task (swap in anything you like)
Search_Query = "How to integrate SAP Shopping Assistant with SAP Commerce Cloud?"

result = run_task_self_refine(
    Search_Query, 
    max_iters=3, 
    min_delta=2, 
    use_agent_for_initial=True  # Use web search for initial draft
)
Setting `use_agent_for_initial=True` leverages the Google Search agent for the first draft when current information might be needed.
Using LLM, I compared all three outputs I got. Here is the result
ItemIteration 0Iteration 1 (Feedback)Iteration 2Iteration 2 (Feedback)FINAL
UI NavigationGenericAsk for detailed pathsAdds named tabs/panelsRequest more explicit stepsClear, step-by-step paths
PerformanceSeparate checklistAsk to integrate in stepsStill separateAsk for actionable guidanceEmbedded, actionable tips
ValidationBrief & vagueAsk to expand per componentIncompleteAsk for full, concrete checks10 concrete, testable checks
PitfallsShort list‚ÄîSameAsk for fixesPitfalls paired with fixes
CompletenessOK‚ÄîCuts offAsk to finishComplete & ready to run
Key Benefits
-Quality Improvement: Typical 15-25 point score increases over 2-3 iterations
-Cost Control: Plateau detection prevents wasteful refinement cycles
-Flexibility: Can use plain LLM or web-search agent based on task needs
-Transparency: Full iteration history shows the improvement process
Quality Improvement Analysis
Score Progress  
Iteration 0:45/100Basic initial draft
Iteration 1:68/100+23 Points improvement
Iteration 2:87/100+19 Points improvement
 
Total Improvement: +42 points (93.3% increase)
 The Answers transformed from vague steps to specific, executable instructions

The simulation shows the typical self-refinement pattern where the biggest jump occurs in iteration 1 (+23 points), with diminishing but still valuable returns in iteration 2 (+19 points).

The approach works especially well for tasks requiring accuracy and completeness, like coding, technical procedures, troubleshooting guides, and detailed explanations, where initial drafts often miss important details.

What surprised me

  • The biggest gains come in the first 1‚Äì2 rounds. After that, returns fade.
  • Weak models can struggle to give good feedback. Strong instruction-following models do best. [ I call them the most obedient models:-)]
  • If feedback is vague, the rewrite is useless. If feedback is dimensioned and specific, the quality of the output excels.

How to use Self-Refine in a Customer Support Chatbot

Self-Refine is perfect for support bots because real customers are often vague (‚Äúmy order didn‚Äôt arrive,‚Äù ‚Äúcan‚Äôt login‚Äù).

Goals

  • Clarify fast when the query is vague and has very less details.
  • Ground answers in your KB/CRM (no hallucinations).
  • Converge in 1‚Äì2 refinement rounds to keep latency low.
  • Escalate cleanly when confidence stays low.

 How can we model this?

TLDR for practitioners

Treat prompts like drafts. Ask the model to critique with structure, then refine under constraints. Screenshot the three steps (Generate ‚Üí Feedback ‚Üí Refine) to make the improvement visible. Once you see it, it‚Äôs hard to go back to one-shot prompting.

Self-refinement works better for some task types (code generation, technical documentation) than others (creative writing). 

Cost vs. quality tradeoff: Calculate the token cost per quality point gained. For some applications, a single well-crafted prompt may be more cost-effective than multiple iteration refinements.

entry.title: TechEd 2025 Berlin: Production Readiness Isn't Optional: A Practical Look at XP265
entry.content:
We all know the drill. Your app works in development, passes testing, and sits deployed on SAP BTP Cloud Foundry. Then comes the inevitable question from management: "Is this actually ready for production traffic?"

If you've ever felt uncertain answering that question, XP265 - Mastering Cloud-Native Applications on SAP BTP, Cloud Foundry Runtime at SAP TechEd Berlin addresses exactly this gap.

The Reality Check You Need

The session puts you in a realistic scenario: 48 hours before go-live with a NodeJS incident management application built on SAP CAP. It's integrated with S/4HANA, follows 12-factor patterns, and looks production-ready. But looking ready and being ready are different things.

You'll work through the actual operational challenges that determine whether your system survives contact with real users or becomes tomorrow's outage post-mortem.

What You'll Cover

Production Readiness Assessment: The sizing validation, derlivery and observability setup that should happen before any production deployment. Not the fun stuff, but the necessary stuff.

Operational Monitoring: How to use SAP Cloud ALM and Cloud Logging to understand what's actually happening in your system. Because guessing isn't a monitoring strategy.

Scaling Under Load: Testing whether your auto-scaling configuration works when traffic spikes hit. Better to find out in a controlled environment than during peak business hours.

Why It Matters

The techniques come from how SAP's own teams handle production operations - the monitoring approaches that catch issues early, the scaling patterns that actually work, and the troubleshooting methods for when things inevitably go wrong.

You'll learn to work with SAP Cloud ALM for centralized observability, use Cloud Logging with OpenTelemetry for distributed system insights, and implement scaling strategies with the SAP Autoscaler that respond appropriately to load changes.

The Details

November 05, 2025 | 1:00 PM CET
SAP TechEd Berlin
Hands-on session with live SAP BTP environments

This isn't a demo - you'll work with actual BTP environments and real operational scenarios. Scenario will be only available on-site during the Hands-On

Gest your spot today & register for XP265

If you're responsible for production deployments or operational support, this session covers the practical skills that make the difference between confident deployments and stressful launches.

This session is part of the TechEd 2025 / Berlin on-site track "Managing your enterprise applications on multi-cloud foundation for SAP BTP - find all other exciting sessions directly in the session catalogue.

entry.title: Re: ABAP test cockpit (ATC) recommendations for governance of clean core ABAP development
entry.content:
Hi @ayush_choudhary37 ,

the error with CL_CI_TEST_EXTENDED_CHECK_SEC happens, because security Code Vulnerability Analyzer (CVA) checks are contained in your variant and CVA is not licensed in your system. You can either remove CVA checks (under Security category) from your check variant, or you license CVA and use security checks. The "Search for customer modifications" check is to find under the "Search functions" category, the "Critical statements" check is under the "Security" category.

Kind regards,
Olga.

entry.title: Designing Scalable Integration Flows in SAP BTP Using Pallets and Adapters
entry.content:
Introduction 

 SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) offers powerful tools through the SAP Integration Suite to design, deploy, and manage integration flows. However, as systems grow, so does the complexity of integrations. This blog explores how pallets and adapters can be leveraged to build scalable, modular, and maintainable integration flows in SAP BTP. 

Why Scalability Matters in Integration Design 

Scalable integration flows are essential for: 

  • Handling increasing data volumes. 
  • Supporting multiple systems and protocols. 
  • Reducing maintenance overhead. 
  • Improving performance and reliability. 

 

What Are Pallets? 

Pallets are reusable integration components that encapsulate common logic. Think of them as building blocks that can be reused across multiple integration flows. 

 

 

  1. Logging Pallet 

             Purpose: Captures and stores transaction details for auditing and debugging.

           Contents: 

  • Content Modifier: Extracts headers and payload metadata. 
  • Script Step (Groovy): Formats log message. 
  • Write to Data Store or external logging system. 
  1. Transformation Pallet  

           Purpose: Applies business rules and transforms data formats. Contents: 

  • Message Mapping: Converts data formats (e.g., JSON to XML). 

 

 

  • Script Step (Groovy): Applies custom business logic. 
  • Content Modifier: Adds or modifies fields. 
  1. Error Handling Pallet 

               Purpose: Manages exceptions and ensures graceful failure handling. Contents: 

  • Exception Subprocess: Captures errors. 
  • Script Step: Extracts error details. 
  • Email or Webhook Adapter: Sends alerts. 
  • Logging Step: Records error context. 
  1. Notification Pallet  

           Purpose: Sends alerts or notifications based on business events. Contents: 

  • Content Modifier: Prepares notification message. 
  • Mail Adapter or Webhook Adapter: Sends notification. 

 

 

  • Router: Determines notification conditions. 
  1. Security Pallet  

          Purpose: Applies security checks or token validation. Contents: 

  • Script Step: Validates JWT or API keys. 
  • Content Modifier: Extracts security headers. 
  • Router: Enforces access control. 

 

You can create a pallet as a separate integration flow and invoke it using the Process Direct adapter, enabling loose coupling and reusability. 

What Are Adapters? 

Adapters are connectors that enable communication between SAP Integration Suite and external systems. They abstract the complexity of protocols and data formats, allowing developers to focus on business logic. 

  1. REST Adapter  

Purpose: Communicates with RESTful APIs.  

Features: Supports GET, POST, PUT, DELETE; handles JSON/XML; supports OAuth2, Basic Auth. 

  1. SOAP Adapter  

Purpose: Communicates with legacy SOAP-based web services. 

 Features: Supports WSDL; handles XML/SOAP envelopes; supports WS-Security.

 

 

  1. OData Adapter  

Purpose: Interacts with SAP systems like S/4HANA using OData protocol.  

Features: Supports CRUD operations; handles JSON/XML; supports OAuth2/SAML. 

  1. IDoc Adapter 

 Purpose: Sends or receives IDocs from SAP ERP systems. 

 Features: Supports ALE/EDI; handles structured IDoc formats; requires SAP connectivity. 

  1. JDBC Adapter  

Purpose: Connects to relational databases.  

Features: Executes SQL queries; supports Oracle, SQL Server, HANA; requires JDBC driver. 

  1. ProcessDirect Adapter  

Purpose: Enables internal communication between integration flows.  

Features: Lightweight; no network overhead; ideal for calling pallets. 

  1. SFTP Adapter  

Purpose: Transfers files over secure FTP.  

Features: Supports file polling, reading, writing; handles encryption and authentication. 

 

 

 

 Each adapter supports configuration options for authentication, headers, payload formats, and error handling. 

 

 

 

Conclusion 

Designing scalable integration flows in SAP BTP is not just about connecting systems ‚Äî it‚Äôs about building a robust, future-proof architecture. By leveraging pallets and adapters, you can create modular, maintainable, and high-performing integration solutions that grow with your business. 

Let‚Äôs Connect! 

Have questions or feedback? Drop a comment below or connect with me on SAP Community. I‚Äôd love to hear how you‚Äôre using pallets and adapters in your integration projects!

entry.title: SAP Integration Suite: What‚Äôs New in Q3/2025
entry.content:
Another quarter has come to an end and it‚Äôs time for us to review the most recent updates and improvements delivered to SAP Integration Suite. Whether you‚Äôre an integration architect, developer, or business leader, these new features are designed to help you get the most out of your hybrid landscape. Read on to discover what‚Äôs new and how these enhancements can support your organisation‚Äôs integration goals.

Message status overview monitoring for large tenants

One awaited featured has been released to the Cloud Integration capability of SAP Integration Suite to improve Message Status Overview monitoring and support larger time intervals through data preaggregation. Now the monitoring option can be utilized for extended periods on tenants with a high volume of message processing logs.

Artificial Intelligence

AI-based integration flow generation with mediation steps

Earlier this year, the generation of integration flows with the assistance of AI was made available to customers. This enable users to generate an integration flow with sender and receiver systems based on a scenario description provided in natural language. You can read more about it here.

In Q3/2025 we have enhanced this feature to include additional mediation steps. This means that now, users can provide even more detailed scenarios and the tool identifies the details and generates a comprehensive integration flow with the described components, systems, and actions. Get a first glimpse into how to use this feature in the blog post: SAP Integration Suite ‚Äì Generative AI based Integration Flow Generation with Mediation Steps.

 Business Accelerators

Joule copilot-based conversational search and discovery of content

Joule has arrived at the SAP Business Accelerator Hub in Q3 to help users find the right content throughconversational context-based search. The Joule-based discovery provides user guidance to search different artifacts and access cohesive information for other relevant sources, such as help documentation.

Note: The feature is currently in the beta phase and you can find more details on availability here.  

Connectivity and Adapters

The latest releases of SAP Integration Suite introduced a new array of adapters and connectors designed to streamline and enhance connectivity, improve data flow, and foster a more integrated digital landscape for businesses leveraging SAP solutions.

AI adapter

The recently released AI adapter for SAP Integration Suite functions as a receiver adapter and accelerates connectivity to the Generative AI Hub (SAP AI Core) and other AI providers, as needed by customer (BYOM).

 The benefit of this adapter is that it increases connectivity options to integrate with both SAP and third-party systems and applications. How it works: after configuration, data exchange is performed at runtime where the SAP Integration Suite tenant sends the operation request to GenAIHub. The AI Adapter works on the request and sends the data back to the SAP Integration Suite tenant.

Find the AI Adapter at SAP Business Accelerator Hub, read the help documentation, and check out the short demo below:

Further adapters released in Q3 include:

IBM MQ adapter using JMS protocol: client certificate supportSupports Client Certificate based authentication for JMS Variants. A new version 1.3.0 of the IBM MQ adapter supports Client Certificate based authentication for JMS Variants.- Configure the IBM MQ JMS Receiver Adapter
IBM MQ adapter using JMS protocol: client certificate supportSupports On-Premise Connectivity via Cloud Connector for JMS Variants. A new version 1.4.0 of the IBM MQ adapter supports On-Premise Connectivity via Cloud Connector for JMS Variants.

- Configure the IBM MQ JMS Sender Adapter

- Configure the IBM MQ JMS Receiver Adapter
BigCommerce adapterFacilitates the connectivity to BigCommerce GraphQL & REST Admin APIs, accelerates the implementation time and reduces complexity of connecting to BigCommerce. This adapter is available on SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

- BigCommerce Adapter at SAP Business Accelerator Hub

- BigCommerce Receiver Adapter

üöÄüöÄDiscover the latest content packages, including APIs and Integrations, released on the SAP Business Accelerator Hub by our partners in Q3 2025. These releases come with high-level details to help you understand their features and benefits.

API-Centric & Event-Driven Integrations

Support for reusable API artifacts in Edge Integration Cell

Customers can now leverage components, endpoints, and services across multiple applications, projects, or contexts, without having to perform significant adaptations. The reusability of API artifacts enables companies to implement a centralized security and traffic management system for exposed APIs. It not only enhances compliance and reduces misconfiguration risks but also significantly lowers both the total cost of development and ownership by eliminating redundant configurations and promoting the reuse of existing API artifacts, which means additional API calls are avoided, leading to cost savings. Learn more.

 

Watch the demo from this year's Devtoberfest - Session "Next generation hybrid integration with Edge Integration Cell":

Integration of Advanced Event Mesh with SAP Cloud Application Event Hub

The latest updates allow you to connect your SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh system to SAP Cloud Application Event Hub for the consumption and exposure of events.

SAP Cloud Application Event Hub creates a clear, user-friendly, and adaptable way to easily exchange business events across SAP's cloud landscape. The solution is a key part of SAP's event-driven architecture. With the integration, you can access events from various SAP business systems, published via the hub, directly on SAP Integration Suite's advanced event mesh.

Migration & Modernization

ABAP proxy generation from service interfaces for current users of SAP Process Orchestration

SAP Integration Suite now supports the implementation of existing use cases for the Enterprise Services Repository using an efficient API-first development methodology. This assists users in importing the service interface artifacts from their PI/PO systems to the Cloud Integration workspace. The feature includes the ability to generate and update ABAP Proxies (non-language-specific interface descriptions in Web Services Description Language converted into executable interfaces) in SAP backend or S/4 HANA systems by connecting them to the SAP Integration Suite tenant and it‚Äôs available in the multi-cloud environment. Find more details and the prerequisites here.

Migration assessment: Clean core modernization recommendations for BAPIs

This extension of the Migration Assessment capability in SAP Integration Suite makes it possible for users to analyse used BAPIs in SAP Process Orchestration. Additionally, they receive recommendations available in the SAP Business Accelerator Hub to transition from legacy content and adopt a clean core approach, e.g. replacing RFCs (BAPIs) with SOAP/OData APIs, IDOCs with Business Events, Alert Rules by SAP Cloud ALM, and more. Explore all modernization recommendations covered in each area.

Dive Deeper

New learning offerings available

Accelerating Hybrid Integrations with SAP Integration Suite on SUSE Rancher Set up, deploy, and operate Edge Integration Cell on SUSE Rancher Kubernetes EngineTime investment 3h, Record of achievement
Accelerating Hybrid Integrations with SAP Integration Suite on RedHat OpenShift Set up, deploy, and run an Edge Integration Cell on Red Hat OpenShiftTime investment 3h, Record of achievement
Exploring Enterprise Automation with SAPUnderstand how SAP Signavio, SAP Build, and SAP Integration Suite work together to improve efficiency and responsiveness Time investment 1.5h, Record of achievement

What‚Äôs next?

  • Integration @ Devtoberfest: watch all sessions
  • Join us at SAP TechEd 2025: explore the Integration track and register

entry.title: Introducing CSA Validation in SAP Cloud ALM: What‚Äôs Live, What‚Äôs Next, and How You Can Shape it
entry.content:
Introducing CSA (Cloud Security Assessment) Validation in SAP Cloud ALM

What‚Äôs Live, What‚Äôs Next, and How You Can Shape (CEI) Customer Engagement Initiatives.


We‚Äôre excited to announce the first release of CSA Validation in SAP Cloud ALM, bringing initial sample checks to help you continuously assess your SAP security posture. As of today you‚Äôll see a new ‚ÄúCSA Validation‚Äù launchpad tile in your SAP Cloud ALM tenant and in the SAP Cloud ALM Demo Tenant. You can also access the validation from the existing CSA application (labeled ‚ÄúCSA ‚Äì Data Stores‚Äù). The new tile is a technical addition‚Äîauthorization and features remain under one CSA application.

Why CSA, and why now?

With SAP Solution Manager retiring by the end of 2027, many customers need a new home for configuration and security analysis. SAP Cloud ALM Configuration & Security Analysis (CSA) is designed to deliver centralized visibility, continuous validation, and governance so you can transition from Solution Manager while modernizing your approach.

Shape the roadmap through the SAP Customer Engagement Initiative (CEI)

  • What CEI is: SAP‚Äôs program for customers to collaborate directly with product teams, provide feedback, preview features, and influence priorities.
  • How it works: Regular feedback calls, early feature previews in demo/preview tenants, structured feedback channels (surveys, workshops), and transparent roadmap sharing.
  • Benefits for participants: Influence capabilities to fit real-world security and compliance needs, gain early visibility of features and best practices, validate against your landscape, and get a direct line to SAP experts.

 

 

What is CSA in SAP Cloud ALM?

  • Purpose: Validate the security posture of SAP cloud and hybrid landscapes against SAP‚Äôs Security Baseline Template and SAP Security Recommendations.
  • How it works: Collects configuration and runtime signals from SAP cloud services and ABAP/on-prem systems; runs prebuilt validations (with a roadmap for custom checks); provides findings with severity, remediation guidance, dashboards, and audit-ready evidence.
  • Value: Centralized, continuous visibility of security gaps; faster remediation with prioritized guidance; alignment with clean-core and cloud governance; reduced audit effort and improved compliance readiness.

 

 

What‚Äôs coming next

  • CSA home screen updated to reflect validation results
  • Ongoing enhancement of preconfigured validations with additional checks
  • Q1 2026 goal to enable customizable reporting on critical and standard requirements from SAP Security Baseline Template and SAP Security Recommendations (limited to already onboarded services)
  • Enhanced data collectors for ABAP systems (on‚Äëprem) and cloud services
  • Event creation from CSA checks
  • Authoring of custom checks and a policy concept for context‚Äësensitive reporting
  • Roadmap update: Publication in progress

Objectives and outcomes of the SAP Customer Engagement Initiative (CEI) for Cloud ALM CSA

  • Co-innovate on CSA capabilities to replace and modernize Solution Manager Configuration Validation use cases.
  • Validate simplification concepts that accelerate delivery while preserving essential security controls.
  • Prioritize features based on real customer scenarios, pilot results, and proof-of-concepts.

Transition guidance: From Solution Manager to Cloud ALM CSA

  • Expect a side‚Äëby‚Äëside period: Security processes may run in both tools for the next two years.
  • Focus on intelligent simplification: Some tradeoffs vs. SolMan are intentional to speed time‚Äëto‚Äëvalue while preserving essential security capabilities.
  • Prioritize high‚Äëvalue controls: Start with SAP Security Baseline and Recommendations; expand as preconfigured validations grow.

Call to action

  • Explore the new CSA Validation tile in your SAP Cloud ALM tenant or the demo tenant.

Together, we can evolve CSA to deliver stronger, cleaner, and more compliant SAP operations‚Äîhelping you move beyond Solution Manager with confidence while embracing cloud‚Äëready governance.

CEI Link (Registration ended on Mar 30, 2025 00:59)

Kind regards,

Arndt Lingscheid

entry.title: SAC Planning & Reporting: The Version Dimension and its Limitations
entry.content:
In SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) Planning, the version dimension is mandatory and unfortunately private. The private nature of the version dimension contradicts the recommendation I gave in an earlier blog post (use of multiple models) but nontheless there are significant reasons to stay with the version dimension as designed. This requires version members to be defined separately in each planning model. It makes early alignment on required versions essential in a SAC planning project. Furthermore, I want to highlight the version dimensions importance in context of the seamless planning roadmap and customer influence opportunities. 

1. Why the Version Dimension Matters in SAC Planning

While some recommendations suggest simplifying the model by using a single version member and managing versions via a custom public dimension, I would not recommend this approach. SAC offers several reasons to use the version dimension as intended:

  • Strong frontend support: SAC provides clear visual indicators for version editing by hitting the advanced button before publishing
  • Private versions: Using the native version dimension ensures consistent handling of version management capabilities in SAC, including the opportunity to create private versions on the fly to plan different scenarios.
  • Roadmap alignment: SAP‚Äôs Seamless Planning roadmap shows continued investment in the version dimension, confirming its strategic importance in future planning capabilities. Building your planning landscape in SAC assuming there is only one version dimension member will create problems when trying to adopt the newest seamless planning features. Check the new blog post of @Max_Gander (Unlocking the Next Chapter of Seamless Planning in... - SAP Community).

For these reasons, it‚Äôs advisable to define all necessary version members upfront and use the version dimension as designed.

2. Limitations of the Version Dimension in SAC Reporting

Besides the private nature of the version dimension there are other limitations.

  • For instance, when you try to use the data analyzer on top of a planning model, SAC forces you to either add the version to the drill or set a single member filter:
  • The "New Table Building Experience" introduced flexibility regarding the version dimension and measures (The New Table Building Experience in SAP Analytics... - SAP Community) in Story Building. But the new experience still has certain restrictions (Restrictions for the New Table Build Experience | SAP Help Portal)
  • The concept of a version dimension is not applied to analytic models in Datasphere. When you are using seamless planning you can bypass the restrictions in reporting regarding versions by defining an analytic model in Datasphere. But there are some widget features that only work with a version dimension, so this is also not a perfect solution.

3. Limitations of the Version Dimension in SAC Planning

When you try to build input enabled layouts in SAC planning, you will be confronted with limitations regarding the version dimension. I will share one use case to show the problem in detail:

SAC has this great "Forecast Layout" for planning. Unfortunately, the sum for the year value is not input enabled (see the green box). So, I tried to build a second input enabled table, that allows total values to be planned (see red box), beginning with the planning of the rest of the year:

Layout:

Calculation Editor "Rest of Year Forecast":

As you can see, the input on the "Rest of Year Forecast" measure works as expected.

But the expectation is to plan the total year value including the YTD Actuals and here the limitation of the version dimension becomes problematic. Since I have to remove the filter in the table widget for the Version, everything becomes read-only:

Layout Forecast and Actuals:

Calculation Editor Forecast with Actuals:

The use of the new experience, or the use of cross calculations does not help to solve the requirement to plan on a measure, that inherits two or more versions, although the inverse formula points to a specific version. I found a solution with constant selection (which I find problematic) and I just hope, that the flexibility with the version dimension will be enhanced in the future. Especially, with the new possibilities of seamless planning coming with the next release, this would be a great enhancement. Data federation in planning is only possible, when the input layouts can be designed in a flexible way. Otherwise, it will be required to copy/paste the data across the planning landscape.

Key Takeaways

  • Although the version dimension comes with restrictions, I would advise you to use it as intended. To further support consistency across models, consider supporting the customer influence to enable Version as Public Dimension in SAC.
  • Restrictions in the data analyzer regarding versions will become more problematic with the new seamless planning release. Please comment, if you find a customer influence. I would definitely support it!
  • Restrictions in input enabled crosstabs regarding the version dimension are an obstacle when trying to build a federeated planning landscape. Consider supporting the customer influence to allow inverse formulas on measures with different versions. If I missed a simple trick, please comment and I will update this blog post.

entry.title: Cell Color and Highlight In Fiori list Report using CDS Views.
entry.content:
A Purchase Order (PO) List Report to monitor the status of deliveries. It is critical that immediately identify which POs are:

  • Overdue: The delivery date is in the past, and the status is still "Open." (Highlight: Red/Negative)
  • Due Soon: The delivery date is within the next 7 days. (Highlight: Orange/Critical)
  • On Track: The PO is open but not due soon. (Highlight: Green/Positive)
  • Completed/Cancelled: PO is closed. (Highlight: Grey/Neutral)

In this scenario, a calculated field is used to assign a Criticality Code to each record, which the Fiori UI consumes to apply the correct color-coding.

The solution involves two main steps:

Backend (CDS View): Define a transient field that calculates the numeric criticality code based on business logic (e.g., date difference, status).

Frontend (Metadata Extension/MDE): Use the Criticality annotation to link the field you want to color (e.g., DeliveryStatusText) to the calculated criticality code field.

Interface View.

AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'INTERFACE VIEW PO'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
define root view entity ZNP_I_PO1 as select from znp_dt_po1
{
  key po_id as PoID,
  po_desc as PoDesc,
  status_text as StatusText,
  delivery_date as DeliveryDate,
  vendor_id as VendorID,
  @Semantics.amount.currencyCode: 'Currency'
  total_amount as TotalAmount,
  @Consumption.valueHelpDefinition: [ {
    entity.name: 'I_CurrencyStdVH', 
    entity.element: 'Currency', 
    useForValidation: true
  } ]
  currency as Currency,
    case 
 when znp_dt_po1.status_text = 'Open' and znp_dt_po1.delivery_date <  $session.system_date then 1   // Overdue 
 when znp_dt_po1.status_text = 'Open' 
 and znp_dt_po1.delivery_date <= dats_add_days($session.system_date,
 7 ,'UNCHANGED') then 2   // Due Soon 
when znp_dt_po1.status_text = 'Open' then 3   // On Track 
 else 0 // Closed 
end as DeliveryCriticality, 
case 
when status_text = 'Open' and delivery_date < $session.system_date then 'Overdue'
 when status_text = 'Open' and delivery_date <= dats_add_days($session.system_date,7 ,'UNCHANGED')  then 'Due Soon'
when status_text = 'Open' then 'On Track'
 else 'Closed'
end as DeliveryCriticalityText,
  
  @Semantics.user.createdBy: true
  created_by as CreatedBy,
  @Semantics.systemDateTime.createdAt: true
  created_at as CreatedAt,
  @Semantics.user.localInstanceLastChangedBy: true
  last_changed_by as LastChangedBy,
  @Semantics.systemDateTime.localInstanceLastChangedAt: true
  last_changed_at as LastChangedAt
}

Updating the status based on the Delivery date.

add the Criticality Field in the annotation For Delivery Criticality text.

Output.

1.When the status is open and Delivery date is not due soon .

2.When the Status is open and Delivery date is  within the next 7 days.

3.When Status is open and Delivery date is in past.

4.When the Order is delivered.

Conclusion:

This scenario helps to quickly assess the delivery status of purchase orders using color-coded criticality indicators. Overdue, due soon, on-track, and completed POs are visually highlighted, allowing faster identification of issues. It improves visibility, reduces manual tracking, and supports proactive decision-making in the procurement process.

entry.title: Dynamic Text Translation in SAP UI with SAP Machine Translation
entry.content:
Problem:

In most SAP Fiori apps, translations are pretty straightforward‚Äîwe rely on standard i18n files and the user‚Äôs browser language. But sometimes, things get a little tricky. Think about texts coming straight from backend APIs or typed in by users. These aren‚Äôt in your standard translation files, and you can‚Äôt predict them ahead of time. So, traditional static translation techniques weren‚Äôt sufficient.

Solution: SAP Machine Translation (Software Translation)

To translate runtime texts, SAP provides an AI-based service through SAP Translation Hub.
Instead of relying on predefined translations, you can send the texts dynamically to the API and get back translations instantly.

Why Software Translation?

  • Designed for short UI texts

  • Allows translating multiple languages and strings in a single request

  • No need for document uploads or static files

How It Works:

  1. Enable Entitlements in SAP BTP

    • Add SAP Translation Hub as a service plan

  2. Create a Service Instance

    • Use the default plan in Cloud Foundry or another supported runtime

  3. Use the Software Translation API

    • Endpoint:
      https://software-translation.api.eu10.translationhub.cloud.sap/translationhub/api/v2/translate

  4. Authenticate using client credentials

    • Use client_id, client_secret, and token URL from the service instance

  5. Send dynamic text for translation

    • Provide:

      • Source language

      • Target language(s)

      • An array of texts that needs to be translated

  6. Render the translated content in the UI

    • Display based on the user‚Äôs current language preference

 

Document vs Software Translation 

 

AspectDocument TranslationSoftware Translation
Best forFiles, long contentUI labels, short strings
Input Type.docx, .html, .pdfJSON payload
API CallsOne language per callMulti-language support
Ideal UseReports, documentsRuntime UI elements
 
For more details, refer to the blog: https://sap.sharepoint.com/sites/210943/SitePages/Enhancing-Dynamic-Text-Translation-in-SAP-UI-with-SAP-Machine-Translation.aspx 

SAP Translation Hub : https://help.sap.com/docs/translation-hub

entry.title: Make Sense of Sentiment: A Step-by-Step Guide to AI-Assisted Context Analysis
entry.content:
Introduction

Ever wondered what your customers‚Äô words reveal about your processes?
With AI-Assisted Context Analyzer in Signavio Lab Space, you can turn unstructured feedback into clear, data-driven insights ‚Äî connecting real experiences with the processes behind them.

Try It Yourself: Step-by-Step Guide

Follow these simple steps to explore AI-Assisted Context Analyzer in Signavio Lab Space:

1) Import the text data you want to analyze as an event log in Process Intelligence. 

Make sure your data includes a Case ID, Timestamp, Activity, and Free Text column.

For a detailed instruction to import data use this guide.

 

 

2) Navigate to Journey to Process and select Create new Dashboard.

 

 

3) Choose your imported dataset, then pick the Free Text column for analysis and click Analyze.

 

 

 

4) (Optional) Link sentiment insights to a process model to visualize how customer emotions correlate with process steps.

 

5) The dashboard will be processed.

 

 

Why this matters

Understanding how customers feel about your processes is just as important as knowing how those processes run. By linking real feedback with operational data, the AI-Assisted Context Analyzer helps you uncover the emotions and experiences behind performance metrics ‚Äî turning raw sentiment into actionable insights. This makes it easier to identify pain points, prioritize improvements, and design processes that truly reflect your customers‚Äô needs.

 

What¬¥s next?

Our context analyzer is currently in beta* and being tested by selected SAP Signavio customers and you can be part of it too. Find more info in this blog post.

*SAP Beta Testing programs provide you with early access to SAP software to test and see how it fits your business requirements. Beta shipments are provided under a Test and Evaluation Agreement (TEA) and can be used for testing purposes only. Productive usage is not allowed and is not supported under the maintenance and support agreement.
